posts.name:
Adam P. Boyd
Adam P. Boyd
posts.content:
8 lessons I learned in a 73mm fintech company 

One fall, I got a call from a company’s COO out of New York.

Their sales team had missed the mark (again), even though they said they are doing everything they can (sound familiar?).

I dove in and from the outside, everything looked great.

But digging deeper, I found a mess.

Their situation is that of many companies I’ve consulted and trained in the past.

Here’s what I’ve learned working with them and many others like them:

1️⃣ Big companies don’t have all the answers.
2️⃣ A sales problem is usually a sales leadership problem.
3️⃣ The usual suspects: hiring the wrong people, not managing data well, running poor processes, not training and developing people appropriately.
4️⃣ A lot of answers are simple ones.
5️⃣ A lot of solutions start with holding people accountable.
6️⃣ A lack of curiosity and a willingness to look at how the engine is running.
7️⃣ Knowing where to look for core issues is a learned skill, but can be taught to smart, hungry, humble leaders.
8️⃣ A refusal to accept “this is how we’ve always done this”

If you’re reading this and sales aren’t where you want them to be.

Where do you need to inspect:

Your data?
Your people?
Your process?
Your systems?
Your training?
How does your customer buy?

Just start looking and challenging the status quo within your org.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------

comments.commentText: not in a hateful way ... the wrong people doesn't mean they are wrong persons ... they just aren't a fit for the company ... but it is actually empathetic or at least compassionate to fire fast ... it allows people to not waste more of their time either as they are are a right fit somewhere ... accountability ... hire slow (the right people) ... fire fast (because it is not fair to your company OR fair to the "wrong person") ...
great word. and a beautiful way of saying it.
Love your point on accountability and clear expectations. That's where I find the issue when I lift up the hood Adam P. Boyd
Albert Ramos Jr. it’s not complicated, is it?

posts.commentAdded: Great insights! Embracing accountability and challenging the status quo can truly transform a sales teams performance. Thank you for sharing!

posts.name:
Neha Rani
Neha Rani
posts.content:
𝑺𝒘𝒊𝒕𝒄𝒉 𝒀𝒐𝒖𝒓 𝑷𝒆𝒓𝒔𝒑𝒆𝒄𝒕𝒊𝒗𝒆, 𝑻𝒓𝒂𝒏𝒔𝒇𝒐𝒓𝒎 𝒀𝒐𝒖𝒓 𝑮𝒓𝒐𝒘𝒕𝒉


Life throws challenges at us, and when things go wrong, it's natural to think, "Why is this happening to me?" 

But over the years, I’ve learned that asking a different question can change everything:
"What is this trying to teach me?"

This simple shift has completely transformed how I deal with setbacks. Instead of feeling stuck, I start looking for the lesson hidden in the struggle.

● A missed opportunity? It taught me patience.
● A failure? It pushed me to improve.
● A tough conversation? It helped me grow emotionally.


 Remember - Every experience, no matter how difficult, carries a message—if we’re willing to look for it.

So, next time you’re faced with a challenge, try shifting your perspective. You might be surprised how much it helps.


Have you experienced the power of this shift? I'd love to hear your thoughts and stories in the comments!

comments.commentText: Neha, your perspective on embracing challenges as opportunities for growth is truly inspiring. The idea of reframing setbacks into learning moments resonates deeply with me. It's amazing how this shift can lead to personal development and resilience in our professional journeys. Thank you for sharing such valuable insights!

posts.commentAdded: Absolutely! Embracing challenges as lessons is a game changer. Thank you for inspiring us to shift our mindset! #GrowthMindset

posts.name:
Jeff Roberts
Jeff Roberts
posts.content:
An article from Vox caught my attention recently—Microsoft's Copilot Vision is taking AI integration to a new level. This tool connects with web pages in real time, offering tailored assistance based on what users are doing. It's not just reactive—it's proactive, aiming to make our interactions with technology feel more intuitive and seamless.

What I find most interesting here is the potential to change how we think about productivity. Instead of seeing AI as a standalone tool, innovations like Copilot Vision weave it into our routines, anticipating needs and streamlining workflows in ways that feel effortless.

What do you think? Are we ready for AI to be this deeply integrated into our lives?

Read more on Vox:
posts.commentAdded: Exciting developments! I believe integrating AI like Copilot Vision can truly enhance productivity. Looking forward to seeing its impact!

posts.name:
Sonia Hunt
Sonia Hunt
posts.content:
𝗛𝗼𝘄 𝘁𝗼 𝘄𝗶𝗻 𝗶𝗻 𝟮𝟬𝟮𝟱: 𝗕𝘂𝗶𝗹𝗱 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗦𝘂𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗶𝗻𝗮𝗯𝗹𝗲 𝗦𝘂𝗰𝗰𝗲𝘀𝘀.


Many leaders are stuck on growth at all costs—
chasing milestones, hustle culture, quick wins.

I'm stuck on Sustainable Success—
building systems that 𝘀𝘂𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗶𝗻 long-term growth.

This is how you impress investors!

𝗪𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗱𝗼𝗲𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗺𝗲𝗮𝗻 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗖𝗘𝗢𝘀?
It means shifting focus to areas,
that are often overlooked, but
are critical for lasting success.

𝗛𝗲𝗿𝗲’𝘀 𝟱 𝗪𝗮𝘆𝘀 𝘁𝗼 𝗔𝘁𝘁𝗮𝗶𝗻 𝗦𝘂𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗶𝗻𝗮𝗯𝗹𝗲 𝗦𝘂𝗰𝗰𝗲𝘀𝘀:

1. 𝗧𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗸 𝗕𝗲𝘆𝗼𝗻𝗱 𝗗𝗮𝘆-𝘁𝗼-𝗗𝗮𝘆 𝗙𝗶𝗿𝗲𝗳𝗶𝗴𝗵𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴.
→ Build resilient systems that reduce dependency on reactive workflows.
→ Focus on processes that free your time for strategic growth.

2. 𝗧𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗸 𝗕𝗲𝘆𝗼𝗻𝗱 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗚𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗱.
→ Prioritize well-being as a cornerstone of leadership success.
→ Invest in daily practices helping you to lead with clarity and energy.

3. 𝗧𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗸 𝗕𝗲𝘆𝗼𝗻𝗱 𝗥𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗻𝘂𝗲.
→ Focus on profitability to reduce reliance on constant fundraising.
→ Align financial health with social and environmental impact through regenerative economics.

4. 𝗧𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗸 𝗕𝗲𝘆𝗼𝗻𝗱 𝗧𝗿𝗮𝗱𝗶𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝗮𝗹 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗵𝗶𝗽.
→ Develop emotional intelligence to lead diverse, high-performing teams.
→ Invest in inner work to grow alongside your venture.

5. 𝗧𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗸 𝗕𝗲𝘆𝗼𝗻𝗱 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗡𝗼𝘄.
→ Ask: Does this decision align with my values and vision?
→ Build a company that benefits people, the planet, and profits.

High growth might grab attention,
but sustainable success is what builds real value—
for you, your team, and your business.

𝗡𝗼𝘁 𝘀𝘂𝗿𝗲 𝘄𝗵𝗲𝗿𝗲 𝘁𝗼 𝗯𝗲𝗴𝗶𝗻 𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗵 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝘃𝗲𝗻𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲? 𝗟𝗲𝘁'𝘀 𝗰𝗼𝗻𝗻𝗲𝗰𝘁.
posts.commentAdded: Absolutely! Sustainable success is the future of leadership. Excited to see how these principles can reshape our growth strategies! 🌍🚀

posts.name:
Jean Larkin
Jean Larkin
posts.content:
50% of U.S. employees are NOT thriving in their lives. 

Let that sink in. 

𝗛𝗮𝗹𝗳 𝗼𝗳 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸𝗳𝗼𝗿𝗰𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝘀𝘁𝗿𝘂𝗴𝗴𝗹𝗶𝗻𝗴. And this isn’t just a personal problem—it’s an organizational crisis.

When employees aren’t thriving, here’s what happens:
 Productivity drops.
 Absenteeism spikes.
 Turnover skyrockets.

According to Gallup’s latest research, we’ve hit a record low in employee life evaluations—the worst since 2009. Even more alarming? The percentage of employees who believe their organizations care about their well-being is well below pre-pandemic levels.

This is not sustainable.

Employee wellbeing is no longer a “nice-to-have.” It’s the foundation for sustainable performance. Thriving employees are:

️ Healthier (less absenteeism).
️ More loyal (reduced turnover).
️ More engaged (better performance).

Yet, many leaders have let wellbeing initiatives slide. They assume that a return to “business as usual” is what we need. That "getting back to work" will fix the cracks. It won’t.

So, what can we do as leaders?

At Octopy, we’ve seen the power of intentional leadership in transforming workplaces and creating thriving cultures. Here are three actionable strategies we teach to leaders:

1️⃣ Listen to understand, not to respond.

At Octopy, we believe that feedback loops aren’t optional—they’re essential. Create systems where employees feel heard and their feedback drives meaningful change. Start small: regular one-on-ones or team retrospectives can do wonders.

2️⃣ Cultivate authentic connections and increase trust.

Our workshops emphasize the importance of empowering authentic connections. Employees need to feel safe being themselves and sharing challenges without fear of repercussions. Trust isn’t just a feeling; it’s built through consistency over time.

3️⃣ Simplify what matters, values-aligned focus helps.

Too often, leaders overcomplicate goals. At Octopy, we help organizations focus on what truly drives impact. When you clear the noise, employees can channel their energy into what matters most—both professionally and personally.

Thriving workplaces are built by leaders who prioritize wellbeing through intentional actions.

At Octopy, we’ve seen firsthand how aligning leadership behaviors with employee needs drives better results, higher retention, and a more engaged workforce.

 How is your organization prioritizing employee wellbeing in 2025? Let me know in the comments.

comments.commentText: Always strive to listen to understand! The response is far less important than understanding. Creating feedback loops where employees feel genuinely heard can transform trust, engagement, and retention.

posts.commentAdded: This is a crucial issue! Intentional leadership can transform workplaces. Excited to see how organizations like Octopy champion employee wellbeing!

posts.content:
Turning a great idea into a great product is a challenge.

And it's one that many entrepreneurs face. 

Enter the Minimum Viable Product (MVP).

But there are some tips you need to keep in mind. 

—


Keep it simple

Build it quickly

Get feedback early and often

Be prepared to pivot

Minimum Viable Product your way to victory
posts.commentAdded: Great insights! Embracing MVP principles can truly streamline the path to success. Excited to see how these tips resonate with fellow entrepreneurs!
